learning_outcomes.description: Understand and apply a culturally safe practice.
Describe First Nations Health in a historical context and analyse the impact of colonial processes on First Nation health outcomes.
Apply and critically assess the role of the determinants of health to global and national First Nations health outcomes.
Apply a health equity framework to analyse the strengths of First Nations led health initiatives.
Apply participatory and collaborative approaches to create sustainable, culturally safe and responsive health policy, services, and systems.
Demonstrate skills in written and oral communication, advocacy, reflection, digital capabilities, and teamwork.

assessments.assessment_title: Critical Reflexivity Portfolio Through Decolonising Lens
assessments.weighting: <dd>45% VLog 1 is 15%; VLog 2 is 15%; VLog 3 is 15% </dd>
assessments.due_date:
VLog 1 (A Personal Standpoint) 21/08/2025 2:00 pm

VLog 2 (Culturally Safe Practice) 11/09/2025 2:00 pm

VLog 3 (Advocacy and Health Systems) 9/10/2025 2:00 pm
assessments.task_description:
A Reflexive Portfolio is a digital collection of your reflexive inquiries into big questions and themes prompted through the Semester in INDH7002. These questions or themes will be weaved through the interactive Modules, Lectorials, Tutorials and Readings. The Portfolio gives students the personal space to dive deep into their own reflexive processes using decolonising lens.

Developing a strong reflexive practice is foundational in being a respectful, culturally sensitive, equitable, and well-informed practitioner, scholar and Ally. Reflexivity is vital to understanding how cultural paradigms and our own experiences influence our worldviews, unconscious biases, and philosophy in healthcare and research. This Portfolio involves three discrete video logs (VLogs). You are asked to complete a Digital Module (each extends on lectorials, reading materials & tutorial content) for each submission in the Portfolio. The Modules will provide you the space to reflect on, in and for culturally safe practice and engage with broader social and political issues impacting health outcomes. Integrating peer-reviewed and grey literature is required for each submission to your Reflexive Portfolio.

  • Module 1 Personal Standpoint Reflexive Vlog Submission Due Week 4 (15%)
  • Module 2 Culturally Safe Practice Reflexive Vlog Submission - Due Week 7 (15%)
  • Module 3 Advocacy and Health Systems Reflexive Vlog Submission - Due Week 10 (15%)


Learning Objectives Assessed: 1, 2, 3, 6
assessments.submission_guidelines: All assessment items are conducted via the ULTRA Blackboard site. This includes all Undergraduate and Postgraduate (internal and external) courses. Instructions are provided for each assessment item on each course site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This quiz is designed to assess students’ understanding of key concepts introduced in INDH7002, with a focus on First Nations health and wellbeing in both Australian and global contexts. The quiz will consist of multiple-choice questions (MCQs) that evaluate students’ ability to engage with course content, including Indigenous perspectives, cultural safety, historical and contemporary determinants of health and decolonising approaches to public health.

 The aim is to consolidate foundational knowledge to topic areas covered in the course including:

  • Indigenous global perspectives
  • Social determinants of health, health inequities and the impact of colonisation
  • Culturally safe and respectful engagement
  • Reflexivity and standpoint
  • Health systems and policy
  • Community controlled services and public health practice
  • Public health frameworks grounded in participatory and strengths-based approaches


The quiz will consist of Multiple Choice Questions (MCQs). Full details, including instructions and access information, will be provided on Blackboard Ultra prior to the assessment week.


Learning Objectives Assessed: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students must complete the quiz by the set due date. Extensions for Assessment 2 (Quiz 2) will not be granted except under exceptional circumstances.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
As a public health consultant, you have been invited to work with a 'mainstream’ (non-Indigenous run/led) organisation. The organisation has heard of the newly launched ‘Making Tracks Together’ Queensland’s Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Equity Framework and have invited you to meet with the leaders of the organisation. You have been asked to showcase the potential value and opportunities of the Health Equity Framework for this organisation.

Purpose: Your task will be to pitch the value of the Health Equity Framework via an oral presentation to the leaders of an organisation committed to health equity for First Nations Peoples. This assessment encourages you to creatively and critically communicate the relevance and impact of the Health Equity Framework. You should demonstrate how the framework supports culturally safe, respectful, and effective engagement with First Nations communities and contributes to addressing racial health inequities.

Modality: This is a recorded presentation with your camera (You may use any medium such as PowerPoint slides or a digital poster or a graphics recording) which reflects Indigenous ways of doing.

Your role: Public Health Consultant

Audience: A non-Indigenous organisation (of your choosing) who are committed to the (chosen) health equity issue (Can be international or local)

Conditions:

  • Oral pitch time limit: 8 minutes (+/-10mins, excludes Acknowledgement of Country)
  • Recorded presentations tool/s: Choose a tool such as PowerPoint slides, digital poster or visual graphical recording style


Referencing style: APA 7th (include a References slide with a minimum of 7 references )


Learning Objectives Assessed: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1:Introduction to First Nations Health and Wellbeing

This session will introduce INDH7002, outlining what will be covered over the 13 weeks, including key topic areas covered in the course, assessments, and expectations. Students will gain an overview of the course structure, learning outcomes, and how each assessment supports their understanding of First Nations health and wellbeing in both Australian and global contexts.


Sub-activity: Podcast – Decolonising Public Health!

Students will gain an overview of the course structure, learning outcomes, and how each assessment supports their understanding of First Nations health and wellbeing in both Australian and global contexts. Sub-activity: Podcast – Decolonising Public Health!

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Identity & Culture: Indigenous Ways of Knowing, Being and Doing

This session explores the foundational concepts of Indigenous identity and culture, focusing on First Nations ways of knowing, being, and doing. Students will be introduced to Indigenous epistemologies and ontologies, which shape how knowledge is understood, lived, and shared within communities.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 2: Identity & Culture: Indigenous Ways of Knowing, Being and Doing

Students will be introduced to Indigenous epistemologies and ontologies, which shape how knowledge is understood, lived, and shared within communities.

learning_activities.topic: Week 2: Tutorial 1 - What does it mean to learn on Country (and on stolen lands)?

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Hidden Histories: First Nations Perspectives on Resistance and Resilience in Pre- and Post- Colonial Context

This session uncovers the often-overlooked histories of First Nations resistance and resilience across both pre- and post-colonial periods. Students will engage with Indigenous perspectives that challenge dominant historical narratives, highlighting the strength, agency, and survival of First Nations Peoples in the face of colonisation, dispossession, and systemic injustice. Through storytelling, historical accounts, and critical analysis, the session will explore how resistance has taken many forms—from cultural continuity and land protection to political activism and community leadership. It will also examine the enduring resilience of First Nations communities, grounded in deep cultural knowledge, kinship systems, and spiritual connection to Country.

Students will be encouraged to reflect on the importance of truth-telling, historical justice, and the role of education in supporting reconciliation and equity.


Sub-activity: Deadly Yarn Podcast – Resistance and resilience of colonisation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples!
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 3: Hidden Histories: First Nations Perspectives on Resistance and Resilience in Pre- and Post- Colonial Context

Students will engage with Indigenous perspectives that challenge dominant historical narratives, highlighting the strength, agency, and survival of First Nations Peoples in the face of colonisation, dispossession, and systemic injustice. Through storytelling, historical accounts, and critical analysis, the session will explore how resistance has taken many forms—from cultural continuity and land protection to political activism and community leadership. It will also examine the enduring resilience of First Nations communities, grounded in deep cultural knowledge, kinship systems, and spiritual connection to Country. Students will be encouraged to reflect on the importance of truth-telling, historical justice, and the role of education in supporting reconciliation and equity. learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Global Indigenous Peoples and Perspectives in Indigenous Health

This session explores the diverse experiences and perspectives of Global Indigenous Peoples in relation to health and wellbeing. Students will examine how colonisation, systemic inequities, and cultural resilience shape Indigenous health outcomes across different global contexts, including Aotearoa (New Zealand), Canada, the United States, and the Pacific. The session will highlight shared challenges—such as dispossession, marginalisation, and health disparities—as well as the strength of Indigenous knowledge systems, community-led health initiatives, and cultural revitalisation efforts.

Students will be encouraged to reflect on the importance of global solidarity, Indigenous sovereignty, and culturally grounded approaches to health that honour Indigenous ways of knowing, being, and doing.

The session will highlight shared challenges—such as dispossession, marginalisation, and health disparities—as well as the strength of Indigenous knowledge systems, community-led health initiatives, and cultural revitalisation efforts. Students will be encouraged to reflect on the importance of global solidarity, Indigenous sovereignty, and culturally grounded approaches to health that honour Indigenous ways of knowing, being, and doing.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Understanding Determinants in Indigenous Health

This session explores the social, cultural, historical, and political determinants that shape the health and wellbeing of First Nations Peoples. Students will critically examine how colonisation, systemic racism, intergenerational trauma, and socio-economic disadvantage contribute to ongoing health inequities.

Students will be encouraged to reflect on how these determinants intersect and how health professionals can respond in ways that are culturally safe, respectful, and equity-focused.


Sub-activity: Deadly Yarn Podcast - Cultural determinants of health: cultural identity, connection to land, culture and language and self-determination!

Students will be encouraged to reflect on how these determinants intersect and how health professionals can respond in ways that are culturally safe, respectful, and equity-focused. Sub-activity: Deadly Yarn Podcast - Cultural determinants of health: cultural identity, connection to land, culture and language and self-determination!

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Rights-Based Approach to Health & Health Equity

This session introduces students to a rights-based approach to health, emphasising the importance of human rights, social justice, and equity in addressing health disparities experienced by First Nations Peoples. Students will explore how international and national frameworks—such as the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP)—inform ethical and culturally safe health practices.

The session will critically examine how systemic barriers and discriminatory policies have impacted Indigenous health outcomes, and how a rights-based lens can support advocacy, accountability, and community empowerment. Students will also consider the role of health professionals and institutions in upholding the rights of Indigenous Peoples through inclusive, respectful, and equity-driven approaches.

Through case studies, students will reflect on how rights-based principles intersect with Indigenous worldviews and contribute to meaningful change in health systems.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Racism as a Structural Determinant of Health

This session critically examines racism as a structural determinant of health, with a focus on its impact on First Nations Peoples in Australia and Indigenous communities globally. Students will explore how racism operates across systems—including healthcare, education, housing, and justice—to produce and sustain health inequities.

The session will unpack the difference between interpersonal, institutional, and systemic racism and how these intersect with other social determinants. Students will also engage with frameworks that support anti-racist and decolonising approaches in public health practice.

By the end of the session, students will be able to identify how racism shapes health outcomes, reflect on their own positionality, and consider strategies for promoting equity and accountability within health systems.

Sub-activity: Podcast - Racism and Anti-racism!

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Health Systems & Policy: Political Determinants of Health

This session examines the political determinants of health and their influence on health systems, policies, and outcomes for First Nations Peoples. Students will explore how political ideologies, governance structures, legislation, and resource allocation shape access to healthcare and contribute to systemic inequities.

Through a decolonising lens, the session will critically analyse the role of policy-making in perpetuating or challenging health disparities, and highlight the importance of Indigenous leadership, advocacy, and sovereignty in shaping health systems that are culturally safe and responsive.

Students will engage with case studies and policy frameworks to understand how political decisions impact health equity and reflect on the responsibilities of health professionals in promoting justice and accountability within public health systems.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Health Systems: Indigenous Community Controlled Health Services in Public Health Practice

This session explores the role of Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisation Services (ACCHOS) and the National Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisation(NACHOS: https://www.naccho.org.au/) within the broader Australian health system, emphasising their significance in advancing public health outcomes for First Nations peoples. Students will learn from First Nations voices and scholarship, gaining insight into the principles of self-determination, holistic care, and community empowerment that underpin NACHOS and ACCHOS.

By the end of the session, students will be equipped to apply culturally responsive strategies in public health practice and advocate for systems-level change that supports Indigenous-led health initiatives.

 

Sub-activity:

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: Community Led: Co-design & Leadership

This session explores the principles and practices of co-design and leadership in the development and implementation of community-based health programmes, with a particular focus on Indigenous communities. Grounded in a strengths-based approach, the session highlights how Indigenous leadership, cultural knowledge, and community priorities shape effective and sustainable health interventions.

Students will examine real-world examples of community-led initiatives that have improved health outcomes by fostering empowerment, resilience, and self-determination. The session emphasises collaborative methods that value Indigenous voices throughout the design, delivery, and evaluation of health services.

Through critical reflection and case-based learning, students will develop skills in ethical engagement, culturally safe practice, and systems thinking to support Indigenous-led health innovation and leadership.

Students will examine real-world examples of community-led initiatives that have improved health outcomes by fostering empowerment, resilience, and self-determination. learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Community Advocacy: Implications for Policy and Practice

This session examines community advocacy in shaping health policy and practice with a particular focus on Indigenous health equity. Students will explore how grassroots movements, community-led initiatives, and Indigenous leadership influence systemic change and challenge dominant policy frameworks. The session highlights the mechanisms by which advocacy translates into policy reform, improved service delivery, and culturally responsive health systems. Emphasis is placed on the role of public health professionals in supporting advocacy efforts ethically and effectively, while amplifying Indigenous voices and priorities.

Students will gain practical insights into policy engagement, coalition-building, and strategic communication, equipping them to contribute meaningfully to advocacy efforts that promote justice, equity, and self-determination in health.

Sub-activity: Podcast - Allyship!

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Reconciliation and Working as an Ally in Solidarity for First Nations Health Equity

This session focuses on the role of non-Indigenous allies in advancing health equity for First Nations peoples through respectful, informed, and sustained solidarity. It explores the principles of reconciliation, allyship, and ethical engagement, emphasising how allies can support Indigenous-led health initiatives.

Students will critically examine the historical and systemic factors contributing to health disparities and learn how to engage in culturally safe practices that centre Indigenous voices, leadership, and self-determination. The session highlights the importance of humility, accountability, and ongoing learning in allyship and provides practical strategies for working collaboratively within health systems to promote equity and justice.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13: Reflection on Your Learning Journey: Upbeat Q & A Discussion

This final session offers a dynamic and engaging space for students to reflect on their personal and collective learning journey throughout the course. The session encourages open dialogue, storytelling, and shared insights, fostering a sense of closure and celebration. Students will have the opportunity to ask questions, share reflections, and explore how their learning can be applied in future public health practice. Emphasis will be placed on growth, transformation, and continuing the journey of respectful engagement and advocacy for First Nations health equity.

Additionally, students will be invited to share their feedback through the course evaluation (SECaT), contributing to the continuous improvement of the learning experience.

At the end of this course, we hope students feel inspired, connected, and confident in their role as culturally responsive public health practitioners
